We asked GPT-4 to decompose questions into a natural hierachy of subquestions, as well as concrete queries it would issue to a search engine.
As expected, HotpotQA requires the fewest sub-questions to answer.

references: To get a sense of how intrinsically difficult         Researchy Questions        are compared to other datasets, we asked GPT-4 how many sub-questions or search engine queries would be necessary to ask/issue in order to fully answer each question. An example decomposition in shown in Table               2             , and the aggregate results are shown in Table               1             . Clearly, GPT-4 thinks that most factoid QA datasets (top of the table) require the fewest sub-questions to answer, whereas         Researchy Questions        require the most even among longer-form QA datasets.

id_table_2.caption: An example Researchy Question, how GPT-4 decomposed it into sub-questions (closed-book), as well the URLs in ClueWeb22 that real users clicked on, and an example of afrom one of those URLs.
table: Researchy Question : how does public transport help the economy Hierarchical Decomposition of the Question Clicked Clueweb22 URLs 1. What is public transport? (a) What are the different types of public transport? (b) How many people use public transport in different regions or countries? 2. What are the direct economic benefits of public transport? (a) How public transport reduces costs for users e.g. fuel, parking, maintenance, etc.? (b) How does public transport generate revenue… 3. What are the indirect economic benefits of public transport? (a) How does public transport reduce congestion… (b) How does public transport increase access to education, employment, health, … (c) How does public transport enhance productivity and innovation… (d) How does public transport contribute to environmental and social goals… 4. How do the economic benefits of public transport compare to the costs of providing and maintaining public transport? (a) What are the main costs of public transport… (b) How are the costs of public transport financed… (c) How are the benefits and costs of public transport measured and evaluated… 1. infrastructureusa.org 2. nationalgeographic.org 3. quora.com 4. accessmagazine.org 5. ced.berkeley.edu 6. greenertransportsolutions 7. bts.gov 8. apta.com Example of a Pivotal Fact from URL: accessmagazine.org “…Even in cities with a high concentration of office space in the [central business district], we estimate that increasing transit ridership by 10 percent will increase office rents by no more than 0.5 percent . For all other cities, we estimate that increasing transit ridership will have no effect on office rents…”
references: The decomposition of the question into a 2-level hierarchical plan (See Table                        2                      Left).

To get a sense of how intrinsically difficult         Researchy Questions        are compared to other datasets, we asked GPT-4 how many sub-questions or search engine queries would be necessary to ask/issue in order to fully answer each question. An example decomposition in shown in Table               2             , and the aggregate results are shown in Table               1             . Clearly, GPT-4 thinks that most factoid QA datasets (top of the table) require the fewest sub-questions to answer, whereas         Researchy Questions        require the most even among longer-form QA datasets.

Lastly, an emergent property of         Researchy Questions        we observed is that some information found in the clicked URLs is very surprising, e.g. for the question “         should the death penalty be legalized        ”, the fact that in the US,         “the cost of enforcing the death penalty cost millions more than life imprisonment”                   2                               2                      2                      supremecourt.gov/opinions                          would have a large impact on the economic arguments in that answer. We define a         Pivotal Fact        as a piece of information that is so surprising and consequential that, once known, drastically changes how an LLM Agent would answer the question (and the answer wouldn’t be as good without it); but it wouldn’t know about it unless it asked the right sub-question to retrieve it, e.g. “         does the death penalty cost more than life imprisonment        ”. Hence, a pivotal fact is the information analogue of a black swan, a critical event that is hard to predict but highly impactful         Taleb (           2008          )        ; another example is shown in the bottom of Table               2             . Although we don’t have a good way to quantify the prevalence of         Pivotal Facts        , we believe that         Researchy Questions        is the best dataset to study the dynamics of how LLM Agents search for, and respond to, these uknown unknowns.

references: Table               3             shows the distribution of first words across         Researchy Questions        (as well as intermediate datasets used in the filtering funnel described in the next section). For comparison, MS Marco queries (also from web search logs) are much more factoid – e.g. only 1.64% of them start with “why”         Bajaj et al. (           2018          )        .

(Right) Search statistics, indicating that harder questions appear in longer sessions. These behaviors confirm our filtering yields more complex questions.

references: In Table               4             (Left) we show aggregate click statistics for each subset of queries. The results show that         Researchy Questions        , which are both non-factoid and decompositional, lead to more in-depth consumption (clicks and sat-clicks) of more diverse information (unique urls), agreeing with prior work         Hassan et al. (           2014          )        .

In Table               4             (Right) we show behavioral signals exhibited by users at the session level rather than individual click level. For instance, if a QnA-type query appeared at any time in any session in the date range, the whole session is included in the “QnA Sessions” row. The results clearly show users were twice as engaged answering non-factoid questions than sessions devoted to factoid-y intents, and six times longer than the average session overall.

id_table_5.caption: Comparison of various question decomposition techniques to prompt GPT-4 as an answer module. The top half of the table is short-form questions, the bottom half is longform questions.
table: Method Samples Direct Answer CoT decomp. Factor decomp. Decomp. Acc. Score Acc. Score Acc. Score Score gain Hotpot QA 300 0.843 83.4 0.877 83.5 0.837 81.3 +0.1 OpenBook QA 300 0.926 86.1 0.843 83.5 0.750 80.7 -2.6 Strategy QA 300 0.757 80.8 0.810 83.7 0.777 82.6 +2.9 Truthful QA 300 0.703 73.7 0.789 82.4 0.739 81.5 +8.7 Aquamuse 300 0.916 83.0 0.940 84.9 0.926 85.0 +2.0 Reddit/askh 300 0.759 79.8 0.736 77.3 0.732 79.3 -0.5 Reddit/asks 300 0.783 81.1 0.743 79.4 0.796 82.7 +1.6 Reddit/eli5 300 0.883 83.1 0.890 85.0 0.890 86.5 +3.4 StackExchange 300 0.717 78.4 0.599 70.7 0.628 73.4 -5.0 Wikihow QA 300 0.93 82.9 0.937 84.4 0.950 88.2 +5.3 Researchy Questions 1k N/A 82.7 N/A 84.6 N/A 88.3 + 5.6
references: Table               5             shows the results of a side-by-side auto-eval of the three answering techniques across a range of datasets. The LLM providing the answers was GPT-4, and the LLM-as-a-judge was also GPT-4, prompted separately using the template in Figure               8             . Since the gold correct answers exist for many of the datasets we consider, the judge was asked to ascertain “Accuracy” as a binary score of whether the candidate answer was consistent with the gold. The “Score” is on a scale of 1-100 indicating the overall quality.The top half of Table               5             corresponds to short-answer datasets (where Accuracy is more important), while the bottom half is longer answer questions where the overall Score is better suited to evaluate. Out of the long-form answer datasets,         Researchy Questions        benefits the most from decomposition techniques.

We draw several conclusions from Table               5             . Firstly, we largely confirm the results of         Radhakrishnan et al. (           2023          )        that decompositional techniques improve the accuracy on short-form multi-hop datasets over zero-shot direct answering.Secondly, factored decomposition leads to the highest scores for long-form questions, particularly questions involving reasoning about complex processes like Wikihow and         Researchy Questions        . On the other hand, chain-of-thought decomposition may be better suited to deduce correct answers to more logic-intensive questions.We believe the results for         Researchy Questions        using factored decomposition would be much higher if we incorporated retrieved information.

id_table_6.caption: Examples of QnA Queries that were non-factoid (had a non-factoid classifier score above 0.75), but weredecompositional (had decompositional classifier scorethan 0.6). Further down this list, more of the examples have a single correct answer (even if it is somewhat long-form), but there is obviously a lot of gray area, highlighting the challenges of trying to filter large amounts of queries by simple thresholds.

references: Again, we chose a threshold by manual inspection to indicate which of the 1.0M           Non-factoid QnA Queries          were also decompositional, which happened to be 0.6 as shown on the right-hand side of Figure                  3                . Out of the 1.0M queries that met the non-factoid threshold, 146k also met the decompositional threshold. These 146k became the           Researchy Questions          candidates           before          deduplication. This procedure is not perfect; in Table                  6                we show examples of some non-factoid questions that did not meet the decompositional threshold.

id_table_7.caption: Examples of incomplete or ambiguous queries a.k.a too underspecified to attempt to answer meaningfully (roughly 3% of queries in the last stage of filtering) that werefrom the dataset by additional GPT-4 filtering.
table: how can climate change why did the market crash are perspectives that change when presented with fresh experiences how did the war for independence end in what ways did native peoples transform how dangeous can a persona affect a person personality how would the law treat the issues confronting a diverse family? how did president lyndon b. johnson respond to this event? compare and contrast social contract what is the difference in how the government reacted in these two situations? how were others influenced by miyamoto explain why summers were difficult for europeans. what effect did the recent looting have on emigration what is the main reason why some teams never reach stage 4
references: As a final quality control step after deduplication, we had all 102k questions labeled by GPT-4 for intrinsic attributes of the question like how           multi-faceted          it is, how           reasoning-intensive          it is likely to be, etc. The full set of eight attributes is defined in Figure                  7                , along with histograms of those scores in Figure                  6                for both           Researchy Questions          and Natural Questions. All eight are scored on a scale of 1-10. About 3% of 102k questions were removed based on the attributes “           ambiguous          ” and “           incomplete          ” which indicate defective questions too difficult to answer; some examples are shown in Table                  7                . Another 2% were removed for being too “           assumptive          ”, meaning the question was phrased in a presumptuous way that was likely to bias the answer as shown in Table                  8                .Another 2% was removed for safety reasons as shown in Table                  9                , where we deem risk of harm too high by attempting to answer the question. Not all “assumptive” questions are harmful per se. Finally, the remaining 96k queries are what we release.

We had GPT-4 label certain attributes of each Researchy Question using the prompt given in Figure               7             . Particularly, we focus on removing questions that were too         incomplete        or underspecified to meaningfully answer (shown in Table               7             ), or those that are too         presumptuous        (shown in Table               8             ). Incomplete queries could arise when users ask queries that e.g. refer to previous queries or subjects in their session.

id_table_8.caption: Examples of “presumptious” queries we removed from the dataset (roughly 2% of queries in the last stage of filtering), roughly defined as those where the question is slanted or biased in some way. Note, not all assumptive queries were harmful.

references: As a final quality control step after deduplication, we had all 102k questions labeled by GPT-4 for intrinsic attributes of the question like how           multi-faceted          it is, how           reasoning-intensive          it is likely to be, etc. The full set of eight attributes is defined in Figure                  7                , along with histograms of those scores in Figure                  6                for both           Researchy Questions          and Natural Questions. All eight are scored on a scale of 1-10. About 3% of 102k questions were removed based on the attributes “           ambiguous          ” and “           incomplete          ” which indicate defective questions too difficult to answer; some examples are shown in Table                  7                . Another 2% were removed for being too “           assumptive          ”, meaning the question was phrased in a presumptuous way that was likely to bias the answer as shown in Table                  8                .Another 2% was removed for safety reasons as shown in Table                  9                , where we deem risk of harm too high by attempting to answer the question. Not all “assumptive” questions are harmful per se. Finally, the remaining 96k queries are what we release.

Table                  9                shows some examples of those removed. Real people asked these questions: we acknowledge that some of these may be motivated by genuine information-seeking intent, notwithstanding, we believe there is too high a risk that the act of answering these questions may lead to harm.

id_table_10.caption: Closed-book direct answers from GPT-4 and Mixtra 8x7bto the Researchy Question used in Table. We find these two answers to be strikingly similar (suggesting convergent evolution of LLMs), and both paint in very broad strokes an answer that isn’t “wrong” but rather, superficial.
table: Researchy Question : how does public transport help the economy GPT-4 Turbo Closed-book Answer (2023-07-01-preview) Public transport provides numerous economic benefits to communities and countries as a whole. Here are some of the key ways in which public transportation supports economic growth and efficiency: 1. Reduced Congestion Costs: Public transport can significantly reduce the number of vehicles on the road, which in turn reduces traffic congestion. This leads to a more efficient transportation system and increased productivity. 2. Cost Savings for Individuals: Public transport can be more cost-effective than owning a private vehicle, leading to increased disposable income for individuals. 3. Job Creation: Public transport systems create jobs for operation, maintenance, and construction, contributing to employment opportunities. 4. Increased Property Values: Good public transport connectivity often increases property values, leading to higher tax revenues. 5. Environmental Benefits: Public transport reduces the number of cars on the road, decreasing air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. 6. Tourism: Efficient public transport systems enhance tourism by making it easier for tourists to navigate and spend in local economies. 7. Business Productivity: Reliable public transport reduces employee tardiness and absenteeism, increasing business productivity. 8. Social Inclusion: Public transport provides mobility for those without access to private vehicles, allowing for greater workforce participation and access to services. 9. Urban Development: Public transport encourages efficient land use and can be a catalyst for urban revitalization and development. 10. Energy Efficiency: Public transport is more energy-efficient per passenger kilometer than private vehicles, contributing to energy security. By providing an affordable and efficient alternative to private vehicles, public transport systems can enhance the overall economic performance of a region and improve the quality of life for its residents. Mixtral 8x7b Closed-book Answer ( https://stablediffusion.fr/mixtral ) Public transportation can have a positive impact on the economy in several ways: 1. Reduced traffic congestion: Public transportation helps to reduce traffic congestion by providing an alternative to driving, which can lead to decreased travel times and increased productivity. This can also reduce the need for costly road expansion projects. 2. Increased economic activity: Public transportation can help to stimulate economic activity by making it easier for people to access jobs, shops, and other services. This can lead to increased spending and investment in local communities. 3. Lower transportation costs: Public transportation can provide a more affordable transportation option for many people, especially those who cannot afford to own and maintain a car. This can help to reduce household transportation costs and free up money for other expenses. 4. Improved air quality: Public transportation can help to reduce air pollution by taking cars off the road. This can lead to improved public health and reduced healthcare costs. 5. Increased property values: Properties located near public transportation hubs, such as train stations and bus stops, often have higher property values than those located further away. This can lead to increased tax revenues for local governments. 6. Job creation: Public transportation agencies and companies create jobs for drivers, mechanics, engineers, and other professionals. These jobs can provide stable employment and contribute to the local economy. 7. Energy efficiency: Public transportation is generally more energy-efficient than individual car travel. This can help to reduce dependence on fossil fuels and decrease greenhouse gas emissions. Overall, public transportation can play an important role in supporting a strong and sustainable economy by providing affordable, efficient, and environmentally-friendly transportation options.
references: The need for more challenging QA datasets also stems from some alarming trends: while there are hundreds of public LLMs, they are pretrained on only a handful existing corpora         Gao et al. (           2020          ); Raffel et al. (           2023          )        , or distilled from one of a few teacher LLMs         Peng et al. (           2023          )        . Furthermore, much more data scraped from the internet for training is itself going to be AI-generated content, leading to an echo-chamber effect         Dohmatob et al. (           2024          ); Wu et al. (           2023a          )        .         Hence, the convergent evolution           Stayton (             2015            )          of LLMs increases the risk that they will           not          recognize that they           don’t          know something        , e.g. see GPT-4 and Mixtral 8x7b in Table               10             . This is especially true when LLMs act in the capacity of LLM-as-a-judge         Zheng et al. (           2023a          ); Yuan et al. (           2024          )        , or when faced with very multi-faceted/multi-perspective questions, where the consequences could be that users “miss the whole picture” or worse, are misled         Zheng et al. (           2023b          ); Liu et al. (           2023b          )        . While retrieval-augmentation         Lewis et al. (           2021          ); Borgeaud et al. (           2022          ); Guu et al. (           2020          )        can help complement LLM agents, the risk is merely shifted to whether a sub-system retrieves the         right        information and uses it correctly         Liu et al. (           2023a          )        .

By design, these questions don’t have a gold answer, so regrettably, it difficult to quantify the “headroom” of existing models, but qualitatively (e.g. Table               10             ) there seems to be substantial room for improvement. There also remains much work surrounding how to measure the quality of sub-questions, and studying how LLM agents find and interact with Pivotal Facts. We hope this dataset can help aid the development of new metrics and unlock new experiences for web users.
